context_meta.summary: Japan's Kobe Steel admitted Friday that a snowballing falsified data scandal had affected around 500 customers, more than twice as many as initially thought. The new estimate comes as Kobe Steel's battered stock fell almost nine percent to finish at 805 yen ($7.20), down more than 40 percent since the start of the week after it admitted falsifying strength and quality data for a string of products -- a practice it said may have started a decade ago.

text: This story is just wrong on so many levels, it's hard to know where to begin. First of all, passenger cars make up a relatively small amount of carbon dioxide emissions. If all of the cars on the planet were electric tomorrow, it would reduce global carbon dioxide emissions by about 2%.  Second, it's the sales of gas powered vehicles that are subsidizing the production of electric cars. For example, General Motors, which apparently is doubling down on it's legacy of building cars that people don't want, is planning to increase significantly it's production of electric cars, which  it currently loses about $9,000 per vehicle. Now that's intelligent; cut back on light trucks and SUV's which are profitable, and focus on money-losing electric cars. Third, as history continues to show, countries or states where electric vehicle subsidies are cut or reduced, sales of electric cars plummet. Without the subsidies, the electric car industry is dead on arrival.

context_meta.summary: Japan's Kobe Steel admitted Friday that a snowballing falsified data scandal had affected around 500 customers, more than twice as many as initially thought. More than 30 foreign customers were affected, including Boeing, Airbus, General Motors, Tesla, German automaker Daimler and PSA of France, according to Japan's leading Nikkei business daily. The new estimate comes as Kobe Steel's battered stock fell almost nine percent to finish at 805 yen ($7.20), down more than 40 percent since the start of the week after it admitted falsifying strength and quality data for a string of products -- a practice it said may have started a decade ago.

It’s called Boom, a Colorado-based start-up that takes time in the process of building supersonic aircraft faster than the Concorde itself and for a quarter of the price. It would fly at more than 2,300 kilometers per hour — 2.6 times faster than any other commercial aircraft.

text: For decades until a devestating crash of the concorde had covered the space between new York and Paris in as little as two hours when a start-up company would take the concorde's design as the goal was to have testing done and pre-production aircraft made by '23.  The goal was to fly between new York and Paris in as little as two hours while another run between Los Angles and Sydney could take as little as six hours.  Like the concorde a ticket on a boom flight would cost at least five grand compared to 20k for a ticket on the concorde.

Amazing how Baltimore/DC metro seems to not be on the list.  It has a population of over a million, several major rail lines, three major airports all of which are airline hubs and two that serve international flights, multiple mass transit options (although they could improve) , and the highest population of educated technical professionals outside of Silicon Valley and Seattle, along with several top universities training multitudes more. There is also something else one can add, people are moving TOO the area unlike the Buffalo and Oklahoma City. Cost of ling is light years below NYC, Miami, LA, and Seattle. Land Cost are also relatively cheap depending on location, with plenty of old industrial sites that have been converted and just looking for tenants, and all of which can hold a facility of 50,000 people or more, not to mention, they already have a large facility here; there really is little reason why not. I know some people are going to false say the region isn't safe, but reality is the crime rate is half that of cities like NYC, LA, and even Seattle.  While there is a murder rate, that is almost completely confined to gang violence, something every city has. 

But lets face it.  When companies perform "contest" like this, they aren't really concerned about little things like building a facility and quality of life.  They are concerned about tax bills and upfront cost.  They are like professional sports teams, they want a free stadium, and the ability not to pay taxes for a decade so that when they pull out, its the city that's left with billions in bills in debt (St. Louis, we're looking at you).

context_meta.title: GM warns Canadian union it could wind down striking SUV plant
context_meta.summary: By Joseph White DETROIT (Reuters) - General Motors Co on Wednesday warned leaders of Canada's Unifor labor union that it will start to wind down production of its popular Chevrolet Equinox sport utility vehicle at an Ontario factory unless workers there call off a month-long strike. Unifor leader Jerry Dias told Reuters on Wednesday that GM officials said they would ramp up production of the vehicle at two plants in Mexico that build the Equinox and a similar model, the GMC Terrain if the walkout is not called off.

context_meta.title: GM warns Canadian union it could wind down striking SUV plant
context_meta.summary: By Joseph White DETROIT (Reuters) - General Motors Co on Wednesday warned leaders of Canada's Unifor labor union that it will start to wind down production of its popular Chevrolet Equinox sport utility vehicle at an Ontario factory unless workers there call off a month-long strike. It’s called Boom, a Colorado-based start-up that takes time in the process of building supersonic aircraft faster than the Concorde itself and for a quarter of the price. It would fly at more than 2,300 kilometers per hour — 2.6 times faster than any other commercial aircraft.

text: A computer never feels compelled to text, point out features along the road to its passengers, rubberneck at an accident site, take a drink or eat a burger, or fiddle with the radio dial or GPS while in operation.  A computer never gets drowsy and nods off behind the wheel.  A computer will make mistakes, because it's programmed by humans, but those mistakes are one update away from being corrected permanently in all computers.  Face it, driverless cars are here.  They are going to be adopted because they let us use the commute time for other purposes and they get us out of billions a year in auto insurance and vehicle maintenance costs.  Bad for lawyers and insurance companies.  Bad for the 4% of Americans that make their living as drivers.  Bad for traffic cops and cities using traffic tickets to fund their local services.  Good for consumers as a whole.  When can I order one up from Uber with my cell phone?
